The idea of a special lacrosse insert was born in
the fall when it was decided that the national champion Blue Jays should receive some of the coverage
they deserve. The result is this special issue, which
is, to our knowledge, the most extensive of its kind
in News-Letter history. "Lacrosse '85" would not
exist, however, were it not for the assistance of
many people.
We thank Coaches Don Zimmerman and Roy
Simmons, Jr., for their help in our coverage of each
of their teams. Jerry Shifflett of "In the Crease"
provided scores of photographs for our use. We
especially thank Mr. Don Fritz for his gracious efforts in recalling a bygone era.
We are most indebted, however, to the members
of the News-Letter staff for their tireless assistance.
Editor Eileen Fitzgerald and Managing Editor
Kathrin Engisch were supportive throughout. We
thank Maria Mitchell, Sharon Fischman, and Brad
Handler for their technichal assistance. Larry Volz
and Jess Bunshaft donated valuable time for the
photography.
We are grateful to our contributors Craig Caplan
and Adam Warner for their skill and punctuality,
to Skip Collins for his sleepless hours, and to
Gregory King and Mary Ginder for their constant
enthusiasm.
Finally, we would like to thank Chuck Maute,
Business Manager, Tammy Huck, Production
Manager, and David Epstein, reporter extraordinaire. Without their time, effort, and dedication,
this issue would be a shell of what it is.

Howard Bregman

David Brengel

Sports Editors
Lacrosse '85 is a special supplement to The Hopkins News-Letter which is published by the students
of The Johns Hopkins University. Editorial and business corespondence should be directed to Box 1230,
The Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD. 21218. Telephone (301) 338-7647. Business hours are
Tuesday and Wednesday, 1-5 p.m. Circulation: The Hopkins News-Letter 6000; Lacrosse '85 15000.

by David Brengel

Returning in the goal is All-Everything Larry Quinn.
The spectactular play of this senior tri-captain last
season is generally regarded as the reason Hopkins won
the national championship. Another strong year by
Quinn could be all the edge the Blue Jays need to
repeat.
It is interesting to note that the last four times
Hopkins has had a first team All-American in the goal
(Mike Federico - 1978-80; Quinn - 1984) it has won
the national title. It is also interesting that the previous
two recipients of first team All-America in the goal
Sears, North Carolina - 1982; George Slabowski, Army-1983) were juniors and were unable to repeat
the tollowing year.
William Tierney will join the Blue Jay coaching staff
for the first time after spending the last several years
at the helm of the Rochester Institute of Technology
lacrosse team. Tierney won the 1984 Division III
Coach of the Year award as RIT made the playoffs
for the first time. Tierney will work with the goalies,
midfielders and the man-down defense.
Returning assistant coaches Jerry Pfeifer and Fred
Smith will guide the defense and Joe Devlin, the offense. Dennis Townsend works with the attackmen and
defensemen individually, and Joe Cowan instructs the
extra-man offensive unit.
With their most difficult schedule in decades, the
Blue Jays must concentrate on consistent play and not
take any opponent lightly. "Every team on our
schedule has the potential to beat us," says Zimmerman,"if we're not mentally and physically prepared.
We looked at the practice schedule and targeted areas
to work on early this year to avoid inconsistent play.
If we have a good attitude, work hard and stay
physically sound, I'm confident of our chances."

ATTACK

All-America attackman Brian Wood

The Blue Jay attack unit appears to be solid this year
despite the loss to graduation of starters Peter Scott
(first team All-America) and Captain Willy Odenthal
(third team All-America), Brent Ciccarone, and Eric
Dressel. The team returns second team All-America
Brian Wood and fourth man Craig Bubier, as well as
Clark Thielemann and Bill Single. In addition, Coach
Zimmerman has added Geoff Nordberg and two
highly talented freshman recruits, Mike Morrill and
John Ciccarone.
Wood was the third leading scorer for Hopkins last
year, both in goals and total points, and should be the
hub of this year's attack. As the attackman with the
most game experience, Wood is expected by Zimmerman to be the "quarterback on the attack," with the
team looking to him "to anchor the unit." Wood
needs to become a more reliable scorer, though, and
his ability or inability to play consistently will have major ramifications for the team.
Outside of the added responsibility of leading the
attack, this sophomore's role should change little. He
will be positioned primarily to one side of the goal,
usually about ten yards out, looking either to drive

towards the goal or to quickly release a shot. Either
way, fans can expect Wood to have the ball often and
to score 25-30 goals this season.
Bubier will join Wood as a definite starter. Zimmerman describes Bubier as "a power attackman who'll
go one-on-one a lot." Additionally, he'll probably
emerge as the unit's primary feeder, although his exact role may depend on who Zimmerman plays at the
third attack position. Tall and agile, Bubier seems a
natural to play behind the goal, but he has added
enough muscle to also hold his own in the crease area.
Last year, Bubier tallied six goals and five assists
despite limited playing time. With his ability to cut
quickly to the net and a hard turn-around shot, this
sophomore's ,mbers should more than double this
year.
Rounding out the starting unit at the crease position should be Single, who has the notable distinction
of having scored on 80 percent of his shots over the
last two years. While he has tallied only four times,
including three last year, the figure is an indication of

The Johns Hopkins Blue Jays enter the 1985 season
as defending champions and the pre-season favorites,
and each game will be a true test of their ability. From
start to finish, the Jays must face the top teams in Prediction: Hopkins 13, Syracuse 11
lacrosse in their quest to retain the title. The following is a game-by-game analysis of this year's Blue Jay

Each year, lacrosse fans talk about why Hobart is
not a Division I team, and how they would fare if they
were. And each year, the Statesmen receive a chance
to prove themselves when they face the Division I
champs in the now traditional Day of Champions
game on Long Island.
Hobart has dominated Division III lacrosse, winning the NCAA championship the last five years. They
have not always done well against Division I schools,
however, losing to such non-notables as C.W. Post.
Still, the Statesmen can play among the best, as
evidenced by their 1983 victory over North Carolina,
which ended the Tar Heels' 26-game winning streak.
The Statesmen are led by attackmen Mark Van
Arsdale (32 goals, 28 assists in 1984) and Tom
Grimaldi(26 goals, 19 assists). Grimaldi was voted the
outstanding attackman in Division III in 1984 while
Van Arsdale was named Hobart's offensive player of
the year. In the midfield, losses to graduation will leave
the Statesmen weakened substantially. First team AllAmericans Jim Holihan (13 goals, 10 assists) and Pat
O'Hara (14 goals, 4 assists) are both gone from the
defending champions' roster.
Defensively, the Statesmen feature second team AllAmerica Dan Whelan on the close defense and junior
goalie Chuck Warren, the MVP of the 1984 championship game against Washington College. The defense,
however, was only able to hold opponents to 122 goals
over 13 games in 1984.
Clearly Hobart has less to lose in this game, and this
makes for a dangerous opponent for Hopkins. The
Blue Jays have to be prepared to play all out.
Prediction: Hopkins 12, Hobart 9

Homewood Field
SYRACUSE
2:00 p.m.
Saturday, March 9
Historical Series: Blue Jays lead, 9-2
Most sports rivalries take time to develop and then
build over many years. This rivalry formed after all
of one game. The intensity of the 1983 comeback victory by Syracuse in the championship game was only
equalled by last year's rematch at Delaware, where the
Blue Jays captured the title. Many lacrosse enthusiasts
are viewing this contest as the rubber game of this
match-up, although it is likely that the two teams will
meet again in the NCAA tournament.
The Orangemen's losses to graduation were
minimal, and their young defense has gained valuable
experience. (For more detail, see the Syracuse team
report.) For those fans who have been asleep for the
past two years, Syracuse relies on an explosive offense
which can strike at any time, usually in bunches. In
this way, the Orangemen are never really out of a game
until time becomes a factor.
The Syracuse defense is not overly strong, and
Hopkins has had little difficulty in scoring against it,
with 29 goals in the '83 and '84 finals. However, the
Jays must limit Syracuse's offensive opportunities by
using ball control and taking the Orangemen out of
their game. Syracuse. has too much firepower to only
concentrate on stopping a Tim Nelson or a Brad Kotz.
There are numerous elements involved in this game,
and any one of them could be the deciding factor. Will
there be a key injury, as there has been in the previous
two years? What about playing conditions? Cold
weather will likely translate into less scoring, which
would tend to favor Hopkins.
The Blue Jays need solid defense, a lot of which
depends upon Larry Quinn's performance. An
outstanding game by Quinn, which is more than a
common occurrence, could tilt the balance. Also, the
attitude of Syracuse coming in will depend a great deal
upon their previous game against North Carolina.
In truth, with two such excellent teams, the deciding
factor is usually desire. Syracuse wants to avenge last

attackmen. On top of this, head coach Terry Corcoran
had an outstanding recruiting year.
The Blue Jays must avoid any complacency. This
game is being played within ten days of the Syracuse
and Hobart contest, and Hopkins may be a little tired.
A lack of intensity could lead to some unpleasant
results. However, Don Zimmerman is too good a head
coach to allow this to happen.
Prediction: Hopkins 10, Washington College 6

Homewood Field
PRINCETON
2:00 p.m.
Saturday, March 23
Historical Series: Blue Jays lead, 39-12
Princeton is usually a solid all-around team, and
they are always well-prepared by head coach Jerry
Schmidt. This year, the Tigers are looking to rebound
from a 2-12 season in 1984.
Defensively, the Tigers return their starting goalie,
Chris Corcoran, but they have lost their entire close
defense, with the exception of All-American Jerry Rizzieri. On offense, the outlook is brighter, with four
midfielders and the entire attack returning. The offensive threats for the tigers include senior attackmen Jon
Lurie(18 goals, 5 assists) and Charlie Stillwell(5 goals,
16 assists.)
Princeton is a good enough team that the Blue Jays
cannot afford to look past them toward Virginia and
the "heart" of the schedule. Still, the Blue Jays'
superior talent should be evident in the final score.
Prediction: Hopkins 14, Princeton 7

Homewood Field
WASHINGTON COLLEGE
3:00 p.m.
Tuesday, March 19
Historical Series: Blue Jays lead, 24-1
Washington College was the runner-up in the 1984
Division III championship game. But, as with Hobart,
don't be fooled by the Division III aspect.
The Shoremen lost their All-American goalie, Greg
Baker, but they return their entire close defense and
first two midfield units, as well as three out of four

Last year's game was a turning point for Hopkins,
as the Jays put it all together to rout the Cavaliers.
This year's game could be more of the same.
Virginia lost standout goalie J.B. Meyer and half
of their starting defense, although recruiting was
strong in this area. Four out of six attackmen return,
including Roddy Marino and Jeff Nicklas.
The key, however, lies in the midfield, where
Virginia suffered significant losses. Highly regarded
midfielder Larry LeDoyen transferred to Hopkins (ineligible in 1985) and workhorse Scott Gerham finished his career with the Wahoos. Both teams can run,
but the Hopkins midfield will be able to dominate and
therefore control the game. In the past few years,
Hopkins has had Virginia's number, and the trend
should continue.

Mac Ford and Gary Seivold. As always, the Tar Heels
will have a fine incoming class, and the entire team
is made up of outstanding athletes.
Any skill advantage that the Blue Jays have will be
countered by the intensity of this game and a significant Carolina home field advantage. This, combined
with warm Carolina weather, should lead to an exciting, high scoring game, and possibly the Blue Jays'
toughest challenge all season.
Prediction: Hopkins 12, North Carolina 11

Prediction: Hopkins 16, Virginia 10

MARYLAND
College Park
Saturday, April 20
2:00 p.m.
Historical series: Blue Jays lead, 42-29-1
Maryland, once a dominant force in lacrosse, has
been on a downslide the last few years. Head Coach
Dick Edell, in his second year, is looking to revitalize
the Terrapins, and his efforts should begin to show
in this year's performance.
While it's always difficult to coach players who were
recruited by someone else, Edell has the good fortune
of returning five of six close defensemen, including
seniors Kevin Hart and Joe Janssens, eight of nine top
midfielders, and the entire attack. And although they
lose starting goalie Kevin O'Leary, the Terps should
have a solid backup in Bobby Virden to take his place.
The sum total is that Maryland will be a much improved team over last year, when it failed to make the
playoffs for the first time in four years, and that
should make for a closer contest than in recent years.
Look for the Blue Jays to pull away after a close first
half.
Prediction: Hopkins 15, Maryland 12

West Point has always prided itself on playing a
tough, physical game, with emphasis on a tenacious
defense. The loss of All-America goalie George
Slabowski and two starting defensemen, therefore, will
take its toll.
On offense, the Cadets rely more on individual
quickness than on teamwork, using one-on-one isolations and few passing plays. One of the reasons they
are able to do so is midfielder P.J. O'Sullivan, voted
the Blue Jays' outstanding opponent last year.
Overall, the contest should be the usual, hard-hitting
game that Army plays. If Hopkins can control the ball
without worrying about the contact, they should be
able to dominate.
Prediction: Hopkins 9, Army 6

This game will be a dogfight. Hopkins and North
Carolina have met six times in the last three years, each
team winning three times. In the playoffs, the Tar
Heels beat the Blue Jays in the 1982 championship
game, while the Jays came back to win two consecutive
semi-final matchups in 1983 and 1984.
The most exciting contests, though, have come during the regular season. Each of these games has been
decided by one goal, including two overtime games.
(Carolina won 13-12 in OT in 1982 and 14-13 in double OT in 1983; Hopkins won 4-3 last year.)
In fact, if this game is anything like the last one in
Chapel Hill, then it's a must game to see. That contest was tied eleven different times until the Tar Heels
won with three seconds remaining in the second overtime, and only after a Hopkins goal with just seconds
left in regulation was disallowed under a good deal of
controversy.
This year's game shapes up a little differently than
in the past. The Tar Heels have lost their two top
defensemen in second team All-American Randy Cox
and the 1984 Defenseman of the Year, Tom Haus(the
former to graduation, the latter to academic difficulties), as well as four of their six top midfielders.
While they return goalie Tim Mealey, their losses will
not allow them to play much zone defense, which was
always a Carolina strength. Head Coach Willie Scroggs
will have to adapt accordingly.
Carolina still has offensive strength, including midfielders Joey Seivold and Steve Martel, and attackmen

Saturday, April 27
2:00 p.m.
Historical Series: Blue Jays lead, 30-25-1
A large crowd should be on hand for this year's
Homecoming game against the Midshipmen. Navy,
like Maryland, has fallen from the ranks of the true
playoff contenders for the last couple of years. This
year, they hope to turn things around.
The Middies' biggest weakness this year should be
the attack, which lost all three of last year's starters,
including Tom Calabrese(26 goals, 10 assists). Coach
Bryan Matthews' offense is not dominated by the attack, but last year's unit scored 48 of the team's 112

midfielder Glen Miles(12 goals, 13 assist) will be moved to attack this year.
This midfield should be strong, with the first unit
being led by Jeff Bellistri (11 goals, 7 assists) and captain Chris Adams. The defensive unit is led by third

to face Hopkins on Homecoming Day. It is not likely

Orangemen, Tar Heels Highlight Jay Schedule
Homewood Field
RUTGERS
7:30 p.m.
Wednesday, May 1
Historical Series: Blue Jays lead, 19-3
If you attended last year's meeting between these
two teams, it's hard not to laugh when you think about
it. The Blue Jays played one of the best quarters of
lacrosse ever witnessed at Homewood in building an
amazing 15-0 lead on their way to coasting to a 21-10
embarrassment of the Scarlet Knights.
That's what makes this year's contest so intruiging.
The 1984 game was a result of several factors. Rutgers
had played Syracuse to a close 15-12 decision only a
few days prior to that game, and actually arrived at
Homewood only an hour and a half before the starting time. They were understandably a little flat.
Hopkins, on the other hand, was well-prepared and
came out on fire, which led to the one-sidedness of
the scoring.
What happens in 1985 depends more on Rutgers
than it does on Hopkins. Despite what you may
believe, Rutgers is for real. The Scarlet Knights suffered some losses, most notably of their top attackman
Bill Naslonski. But they return standout goalie John
Naslonski and most of their defense and midfield.
What may be most important is that Rutgers returns
with an extra year's experience. To witness the results,
one need go no further than looking at the Knights'
9-3 defeat of Syracuse in the fall. And while it was only
fall ball, it has certainly boosted Rutger's confidence.
Rutgers fields a young but very talented team.
Against Hopkins last year, they employed three different longstick units, and they returned eight of the
nine members. Throughout the lineup they have quality players; the Scarlet Knights may soon be ready to
break into the upper echelon of college lacrosse.
An important factor in this year's game is that once
again, Rutgers will face Syracuse and Hopkins consecutively on the road. The outcome of the Hopkins
game, therefore, will depend upon the results of the
Syracuse contest.
The real reason that this game depends so much

upon Rutgers, though, is last year's game. The
memory of that crushing defeat will be ever present.
This will lead to one of two results. Rutgers can use
that defeat in a positive way, to fire themelves up for
a revenge match, or they could be haunted by it, and
expect the same to happen again this year. The former
will lead to a good game, the latter to another blowout.
Rutgers has a fine coaching staff, so they will undoubtedly be more prepared this year. Still, as long
as the Blue Jays are also prepared, they should come
away with a win.

12LAX/MARCH 8, 1985

A small but skillful class

Five Freshman Give '85 Jays A Dose of Talent
by Adam Warner
The 1985 season marks the first year that players
recruited by Don Zimmerman as head coach will put
on the Blue Jay uniform. Only five freshmen join the
squad from the class of '88, but all five were high
school consensus • All-Americans in their senior
seasons. Though it is unlikely that any will make as
big an impact this year as Brian Wood did as a frosh
in '84, before they graduate they should prove to be
as good as any other class of recent memory. If
nothing else, three of the five have names and family
ties quite familiar to Blue Jay loyalists: Ciccarone,
Morrill, and Dressel.
The first is John Ciccarone, son of Henry Ciccarone, Sr., who preceded Zimmerman as Hopkins'
head coach, and brother of former Blue Jay stars Brent
and Henry, Jr. Like Brent, John plays attack, and in
•high school he was truly exceptional. He was a four
year varsity player at Boys Latin in Baltimore, and in
the words of his former coach Bobby Shriver,"he just
got better and better every year. Last year, he had what
I'd call a truly outstanding season."
The team had a fine year as well, as they made it
to the area finals, where they lost 8-6 to a Loyola team
that they had beaten six days earlier. According to
Shriver, "If we had won that game, Ciccarone would
have been named Metro Player of the Year."
Shriver is also quick to praise Ciccarone's intensity
toward the game. "He'll work as hard as anyone you'll
see. He's been lifting weights in order to bulk up for
his college career. He has all the tools to be an excellent
player."
It seems as if the only problem that Ciccarone may
have is his size. At 5'10" and 160 lbs., he is by no
means tiny, but in major college ball he will be facing
big defensemen every game, and that may get tough.
Also joining the attack is Mike Morrill, a third
generation Blue Jay. His grandfather, Kelso, played
for Hopkins in the 1920's, while his father, Bill, was
a star in the early 1960's.

If any frosh is to play a big role in Hopkins' national championship defense, it will likely be Morrill.
He has the size at 6'0", 185 lbs., excellent skills and
of course, the genes. In the scrimmage against Penn,
he led Hopkins with three goals.
Morrill played his high school ball at St. Paul's in
Brooklandville for George Mitchell, himself a former
Blue Jay as well as the father of defenseman Steve
Mitchell.
The new Dressel is John Dressel, brother of the better known Del. John will also play midfield, although
the two will not team on the same line.
A Baltimore native, John starred for Lawrenceville
Prep in New .,:rsey. Though he only played there for
one season, his coach Marshall Chambers ranks him
among the best players he's had; one who helped his
program immensely. Particularly impressive were his
stick skills, which Chambers called "the very best I've
seen it this level of play."
At Lawrenceville, Dressel played on attack, "mainly
because we had.some fast midfielders," says
Chambers. "Besides," he adds, "it was better having
him on the field more often."
In analyzing •Dressel's future as a Blue Jay,
Chambers sees no problems down the road. "Here,
we lacked a whole team to surround him, but at
Hopkins he'll be playing with nine other excellent
players."
Hopkins' other midfield recruit is Joe Rzempoluch.
He hails from Farmingdale High School on Long
Island, a virtual factory that has also produced current Hopkins stars John Krumenacker, John DeTommaso and Bruce Chanenchuk.
Right now, Rzempoluch may be the best prepared
of his class to move into a key position. At 6'0", 190
lbs., he has the size, and coming from Farmingdale
he was brought up in a style of play similar to that
of Hopkins. Harntranft, his high school coach,
believes that Joe will "fit in very well to Coach Zimmerman's system. Here, like at Hopkins, midfielders
bring the ball up very quickly on offense, while they

HOW
CAN YOU
LOSE WITH GUYS
LIKE THIS ON
YOUR TEAM?

are all required to play excellent defense." Rzempoluch
particularly excelled at the defensive phase of the
position.
Aside from being named All-America, Rzempoluch
won the Jim Brown Award as the area's best midfielder. Yes, it's THE Jim Brown. As for Farmingdale,
they finished their year at 17-2, the number one seed
in their region before being upset in the playoffs.
Last, but not least, Hopkins brought in Jeff Kramer,
a goalie. Kramer attended Worthington High School
in Ohio, as he is the only player on the squad this year
not to come from an Atlantic state.
Though highly talented, Kramer will not see much
action at all this year in the nets. All three goalies from
1984 return, including NCAA tournament MVP Larry
Quinn, who is unquestionably the best goalie in the
country. The 5'10", 160 lb. freshman will get his big
chance next year, when he will battle sophomore Stuart
Jones and any other newcomers for the starting slot.

The Sieve Story
If you've been wondering what those strange people with kitchen utensils have been doing at lacrosse
games, you need not wonder any more. They're sieves.
No, not the people, the utensils. The tradition actually began at Cornell hockey games. The chant of
"sieve" is directed at the opposition's goalie, hoping
that he will let pucks(or in our case lacrosse balls) pass
through, as a sieve allows objects to pass through.
When done effectively, it has been known to rattle
many a goaltender.
The tradition was brought to Hopkins by two
students, Mark Lazarus and David Epstein, for the
1983 playoff game between Hopkins and Cornell.
Sieves can be purchased at any food store for a small
price. Colanders and other sorts of strainers are acceptable, but they're not the genuine article. So, get
yourself a sieve, head out to the game, and abuse the
other team's goalie.

LACROSSE '85/13LAX

An Interview with Coach Roy Simmons, Jr.
The coach of the Orange discusses his teams, Hopkins, and the future.
Editor's Note: Roy Simmons, Jr., the head coach of the
Syracuse lacrosse team, spoke with Howard Bregman and
David Epstein of the News-Letter on February 21st. We thank
Coach Simmonsfor his time and his help with our coverage
of the Orangemen.

N-L: Could you sum up the team's attitude going into the game with Hopkins? Is the outlook different
after having been in the finals for two years?
Simmons: Well, we don't play Hopkins normally in
the regular season. We've played in the playoffs, and
stubbed their toe. It's important to get a shot at
Hopkins and not have to wait until May, if that's a
possibility at all. ..Of course, we start off up here with
North Carolina on the fifth of March, so I think that
that puts the Blue Jays second; we're thinking more
about the Tar Heels right now, we know that that game
will be very important.
N-L: So you'll be travelling right after the Carolina
game by bus?
Simmons: Yes, we're going to come down the night
of the seventh, so we'll be there for two nights. We'll
have a workout on the eighth; but we'll arrive in
Baltimore on the night of the seventh. That's two days
after our Carolina game.

So we look very good on paper.

THE LACROSSE NEWS MAGAZINE

LACROSSE '85/15LAX

Orangeman Lacrosse:

Steve Parker: Syracuse SI

by David Epstein
In order to build a top college lacrosse program, a
school must have a strong high school recruiting base.
Logic would therefore dictate that the wider the
recruiting area, the more talent that would be available
and therefore the more successful the program. Under
this assumption, the Syracuse lacrosse team has
managed to defy logic.
For the past half decade, two teams have dominated
New York state high school lacrosse. Downstate,
Yorktown High School (Westchester County) has
reached the state final in five consecutive years, capturing the title in 1984. In doing so, each year
Yorktown has had to defeat the top team on Long
Island.
Upstate, West Genesee High has been so dominant,
that it borders on the unbelievable. The Wildcats have
been to the state finals the last four years, winning
three times. Along the way, they tied a state record
by winning an astounding 91 consecutive games, a
streak which was broken in last year's state finals by
Yorktown.
Not surprisingly, these two schools have consistently
turned out top players and more than their share of
All-Americans. What is surprising is that Syracuse has
been able to build a championship program basically
around players from these two high schools. Syracuse
Head Coach Roy Simmons, Jr. is quick to deny this
idea, and he points out that his team has players from
Maryland and Massachusetts. However, the
undeniable evidence is that eight of the Orangemen's
ten starters, and over one third of the team, are from
either West Genesee or Yorktown. Of course, this
means that there are also many Syracuse players from
other areas; many top players from both West Genny
and Yorktown have opted to attend other colleges.
Still, Simmons has used the emergence of lacrosse in
Westchester and Central New York to his advantage
as no other coach has been able to do.
For Syracuse, this has translated into two consecutive championship caliber teams. The 1983 team
was victorious in the finals, the 1984 team was the
runner-up, and both times they faced Hopkins. Unfortunately for the rest of lacrosse, the 1985 Syracuse
squad may be their strongest ever.
The Syracuse style of play is to use a highly potent
offense and an unspectacular defense to outscore their
Opponents. They often have trouble in tight defensive
games, but almost always win a shutout. The
Orangemen's ability to score is almost uncanny, and
When they score a goal, there are usually two or three
more to follow. It is this type of streak scoring that
has characterized the Syracuse team, and, not surpris-

Syracuse at a Glance

ingly, it is a trademark
of the West Genesee
High team also.
The main force behind
Syracuse's scoring ability
is their attackmen, who
last year accounted for
149 (or 55%) of the
team's 262 goals. This
year's unit is already being considered the most potent attack in the country. It
consists, not surprisingly, of one
player from West Genesee and two from
Yorktown.
The leading attackman for Syracuse is senior
Tim Nelson (Yorktown). All Nelson has done in
his two years at Syracuse (his freshman year was
spent at N.C. State) is amass 186 points, being
named to the first team All-America squad and winning the Turnbull Trophy as outstanding Division I attackman both years. Nelson plays behind the goal and
literally runs the offense, using his accurate passing
ability to pile up assists at an incredible pace. He was
injured in the championship game last year, and is
reported to be one hundred percent after surgery and
rehabilitation. Although he will be wearing a brace
during the season, it is not likely that it will affect his
play.
With a Tim Nelson behind the goal, one might think
that all the other attackman need do is be the recipient
of Tim's passes, simply pumping in the goals. And in
one case, this is not far from the truth. Junior Tom
Korrie, out of West Genesee, piled up 51 goals last
season on his way to earning third team All-America
honors. A fine player in his own right, Korrie thrived
on Nelson's passing ability in his becoming Syracuse's
leading scorer last year. In light of this, what perhaps
could be considered less than all-around play on Korrie's part makes him no less dangerous.
The third attackman, sophomore Tom Nelson, may
best be known as Tim's younger brother, although he
came into prominence last year in the championship
game by scoring 3 goals after replacing brother Tim.
This year, Tom will be filling the spot vacated by the
graduation of Randy Lundblad. What people may
soon observe, though, is that Tom Nelson may be the
best all-around attackman on the team. He may not
pile up the statistics that others will(though he did have
21 goals and 16 assists in limited duty last season), but
he can play the crease, scoop up ground balls, hit, feed
and score. In sum, he is a dedicated, total player. Tom
becomes all the more dangerous teamed with Tim, who
he has practiced and played with for most of his life.
If that were not enough depth at attack, junior Emmett Printup is available in case of injury or just to
give someone a rest. Printup had a hat-trick in last
year's finals and received recognition for his play in
the World Lacrosse Competition held at Los Angeles.
Clearly, in order to stop Syracuse, one must stop their
attack—all of their attack.

Turning to the midfield, Syracuse may actually be
slightly weaker than in the past two years. Key losses
for the Orange include second team All-America Dave
Desko and face-off man Mark Burnam. Still, the first
midfield unit should be among the best in lacrosse.
Leading the top line is two-time first team AllAmerica and 1983 Player of the Year Brad Kotz(West
Genesee). Kotz faces off for that line with mixed
results, but more importantly, he can ignite the team
at any moment, as evidenced by his 31 goals and 30
assists last season. Kotz is clearly the line's leader as
well as being its best player.
The second member of the first line, Todd Curry,
is also from West Genesee. Curry, a sophomore,
became a member of the first midfield as a freshman.
While he is not as prolific a scorer as a Kotz, his outside shot is among the best around. Last season he had
11 goals, but you can rest assured that most of them
were bullets.
The second midfield will be led by sophomore Pat
Donahue, that line's face-off man. He will most likely be joined by John Schimoler, a senior who had a
solid season in 1984. The third spot will be filled by
a player yet to be determined, depending upon early
play against Carolina and Hopkins. Coach Simmons
will use these games to establish a definite line for the
rest of the year.

In any case, there will likely be a great disparity between the first and second midfield lines. While the first
midfield accounted for 47 goals and 39 assists last
season, the second midfield (depending upon its third
member) will have tallied last year, no more than 19
goals with just 6 assists. Because of this, the second
line becomes more of a supplement to the high
powered attack than a dangerous unit of its own.
Syracuse returns their close defense intact, and the
added year of experience should be a big plus. Junior
Kevin Sheehan was a third team All-America last
season, and this year he will lead the defense as a team
co-captain. Joining Sheehan will be another junior and
honorable mention All-America, Jeff Desko (West
Genesee),as well as sophomore Mike O'Donnell
(Yorktown). The three play well as a unit, but still cannot compare with other top defenses. It remains to be
seen how well they will have progressed from last year.
Experience on defense can mean a lot, and the difference could be significant. The rope defense of Dan
Pratt, Fred Opie and Chris Burt should see some action, although Simmons does not plan to overly rely
on the unit.
The Syracuse goalie will once again be Tom Nims.
Nims, a senior from West Genesee, was named
honorable mention All-America in 1984. He is not a
spectacular goalie, but plays solidly throughout the
season. Like most goalies, though, if he becomes hot,
he can be tough to penetrate. Syracuse is also fortunate
to have a top backup goalie in Tom Gygory, a junior
out of Annapolis. Simmons will probably not hesitate
to use him should the situation call for it.
In sum, the Syracuse team is much like those of the
recent past. They will rely heavily on the attack and
first midfield for some high scoring, while hoping that
the second midfield and defense can hold their own.
But the key to this year's team could be experience.
The defense has played together for a full year, and
the only real newcomer to the first string is Frank
Lanuto, and he is a senior. Also, players such as Tim
Nelson, Brad Kotz and Tom Nims are seniors, and will
be hungry for a championship in their final year. This
desire may be Syracuse's most potent weapon of all.

16LAX/MARCH 8, 1985

The Championship Teams of '50 and '84: A
Separated by 34 years, the two squads represent
When making such a comparison, a complete
perspective is required. One must examine all four
years of each team's existence: 1981-1984 and
1947-1950.
A comparison of teams or, for that matter, players
of different eras is a delicate undertaking. In the case
of these two magnificent squads, fortunately, most of
the participants are still with us. The author is one of
those people who feel that lacrosse is a sport that
makes an enthusiast's liver curl with enjoyment. I am
of the opinion that the nuances and intricacies of the
game demand more knowledge than most other sports;
I am privileged to have witnessed the majority .of
games each team played. Therefore, I shall state facts,
cite quotations, and let the reader form his own
opinion.
Bill Tanton, sports editor of the Evening Sun, stated
in a recent article, "Actually, the 1950 team, as
everyone calls it, was four teams, from 1947-1950.
Many argue they were the best four teams in the
university's history, and if they were, the 1948 squad
probably would have to rank immediately behind the
1950 team on the all-time list. That was the final year
for Brooke Tunstall and Ray Greene, two of the best
ever to play for the Jays."
Due to conditions created by wartime, both Tunstall
and Greene earned first team All-America lacrosse .
honors at two different universities, the former at Cornell and Hopkins, the latter at Drexel and Hopkins.
Many knowledgeable lacrosse personalities familiar
with Hopkins teams over 60 years were interviewed by
Tanton concerning their choice of JHU's greatest
teams. These were analyzed and finally released a few
years ago by the one-time News-Letter sports editor
and Hopkins varsity player. He continues to rate the
squad of 1950 as his top team in Johns Hopkins
history.

"The 1984 team is much stronger
and quicker. They work with weights
and can probably bench-press 75 or 100
pounds more than we could."
-Wilson Fewster
The success of the two teams is self-evident. The
1950 team members felt good about themselves and
in turn produced brilliant results. They played and won
31 consecutive intercollegiate games over four years,
losing only 4 games to club teams. The 1984 squad won
14 intercollegiate games, or almost half that amount,
in one year. No play-off system existed in 1950, nor
were mid-week games played.
The game itself has changed much in the 34 years
that separate these teams. A momentous disparity exists in the physical equipment used. Besides basic
athletic shoes, padding, and jerseys, each 1950 player
carried a wooden stick with a gut wall and a leather
and gut strung net. These sticks were usually made by
Indians in Canada. Since then, a quantum leap forward in the technology of lacrosse sticks has been
made. All male players today use a hollow aluminumhandled stick with a synthetic plastic double-walled
head strung with nylon cord netting. These modern
factory-manufactured sticks are perfectly balanced.
The old wooden ones seldom were. Experts claim the
ball tends to settle in the modern-type nets more readily
than in the old gut and leather type.
The late, legendary Frenchy Julien, closely
associated with lacrosse for 60 years, commented, "I
cannot understand how a player can miss catching a
ball with today's equipment."
In 1950 all games were played on natural grass. Today, most games are played on astroturf. A bouncing
ball becomes predictable. Many old-timers recall
scooping a net full of mud to retrieve a ball.
An obvious dissimilarity relates to substitutions. The
1950 squad ran midfields as units into games, replacing one unit for another to catch its breath. Coaching
philosophy in 1984 has changed in sophistication.
There are more specialists today. For example, a
center, once he gains possession after a face-off, will

Glancing at programs of the two periods, major differences in personnel are obvious. All of the participants but one on the 1950 team were from the
Baltimore metropolitan area. In 1984, the majority of
players hailed from outside Baltimore. The secondary
school graduates of the three major hot-beds of
lacrosse, Baltimore, upper New York state, and Long
Island, presently have a larger selection of lacrosseplaying colleges to attend.
The vast majority of the lacrosse team in 1950, with
little or no inducement, voluntarily attended Johns
Hopkins. In 1984, recruiting high school lacrosse talent
is the norm for most colleges and universities that are
serious about the sport. In 1950, exactly half of the
players were service veterans and they received monthly subsistence checks. Most native Baltimoreans lived
at home.
Karl Levy, captain of the 1926 team, who continues
to attend Hopkins games, once stated, "The 1950 team
was the best I have seen. Those fellows in 1950 had
a certain maturity because their college had been
delayed by the war. They were men, not boys. The
1984 team was a surprisingly great team. They were
clever and showed much finesse. The game today is
much smoother and more graceful."
"Karl Levy might well make a case for his own 1926
team which was 9-0 and gave up only 11 goals," wrote
Bill Tanton. "But the 1950 squad was so deep in talent
stockpiled after World War II that we shall never again
see anything like it."
In 1984, the G.I. Bill, as we knew it is no more.

"I believe the 1950squad contained
better all-around athletes because most
of us played other sports. We had a
superior close defense."
-Tom Gough
Tuition, room, and board are now major factors when
a talented lacrosse player considers college. Hopkins,
in order to compete with universities granting hill
scholarships, found it necessary some years ago to adjust its athletic philosophy. The university's commitment to pure amateurism in intercollegiate sports continues largely unchanged. Full athletic scholarships are
not awarded to Hopkins students. All athletes must
meet the University's admission requirements. Limited
financial aid is available; if there is a need, Johns
Hopkins will listen.
Furthermore, an athlete at Hopkins is presently
penalized due to NCAA regulations pertaining to

financial aid. An athlete receiving scholarship aid in
lacrosse, a Division I sport at Hopkins, cannot participate in a Division III sport such as football. Only
two members of the 1984 lacrosse team, due to the arrangement of their aid, were able to play another sport.
Almost half of the 1950 team participated in two or

There are lacrosse players today with the necessary
academic credentials attending Hopkins because that
is where they wish to go. The same situation existed
in 1950. Because there are considerably more secondary schools playing lacrosse today in many areas of
the country than there were in 1950, there exists a
greater quantity of good quality lacrosse talent.
The convenience of modern athletics also separates
these two teams. When Hopkins played Princeton in
1950, for example, the team bus would leave early
Saturday morning to travel to Princeton. After their
arrival, players would get dressed, warm up, play the
game, and then return to Baltimore the same day. In
1984, the team left on a Friday, arriving in time to
practice. The squad ate lunch, dinner, and a Saturday morning meal together. This schedule helps to settle a team down and makes for a better organized and
cooperative effort.
The 1950 team played four years without an intercollegiate loss, winning four straight national championships. In its senior year, it conveyed an impression of invulnerability. The 1984 team, prior to their
undefeated national championship season, suffered an
occasional loss, including heartbreaking defeats in
three preceding championship finals.
A clear cut comparison indicates the 1950 team produced two first team All-Americans, one second team,
and two third team selections. Over its four years, including honorable mentions, the 1950 team generated
a total of 41 All-Americans. The entire 1950 first team
earned All-America recognition some time during its
four years. Interestingly, over their four years, eleven
1950 players were named to the All-Time J HU Team,
nine in the year 1950 alone, which is more than any
team in the university's history, before or since.
The 1984 squad produced four first team AllAmericans, two second team and one third team selection. Over its four years, including honorable mention,
the team generated a total of 28 All-Americans. During the four year span from 1981 to 1984, two players
were named to the All-Time JHU Team.

Single's ability to put the ball on goal and to get open

and expects him to be a major part of the attack unit.
"Bill does the things a creaseman needs to do," said
Zimmerman."He also hangs in there on the screens."
Thielemann improved greatly last year and peaked
with a three-goal Performance against Rutgers. This
pre-season he has played well, scoring mostly from the
crease area, although Zimmerman has indicated he
would not use Thielemann as the creaseman. It is

possible Thielemann will start some games this season,
though he should see abundant playing time regardless
of his role. "A versatile, steady player," is Zimmerman's description,"who is capable of spelling any of
the three starters." If his progess continues, this
Centennial product should emerge as a big contributor.
Morrill, an All-American at St. Paul's High School
last year, has already shown he has the talent to
challenge both Single and Thielemann for the third
starting position. Zimmerman sees Morrill as a strong,
heady player who can do well either in the crease or
behind the goal. Chances are that Morrill will not start
versus Syracuse, but Zimmerman probably will not

hesitate to use him should the offense sputter.
Ciccarone is another Baltimore product and the
third brother to play for Hopkins, following Henry
and Brent. An All-American at Boy's Latin prep
school, Ciccarone should see limited action this
year as Zimmerman has indicated he'll be used
primarily as a left-handed back-up.
,Nordberg transferred from Maryland two years ago,
but has yet to play on the squad. He has played fairly
well throughout pre-season, though it is doubtful he
will see much action this year unless there is a rash of

_

Leading Hopkins' second midfield unit will be
Mutscheller. A quick cutter to the crease, Mutscheller
has become a good, smart inside player, according to
Zimmerman, and should have his best games versus
opponents playing a zone defense. As the seventh
leading scorer for the Jays last year, Mutscheller will
be expected to carry a large part of the scoring load
and to fill the void left by Tucker, his former linemate.
While his performance will depend to some extent on
whoever is feeding from behind the net, Mutscheller
should be one of the midfield's top five contributors.
Schreiber will team with Mutscheller and give the
second line diversity with his ability to drive to the goal
from the outside. Big and strong, Schreiber has shown
that he can muscle over defenders, which should open
things up inside fol- his linemates. The junior scored
11 goals last year, including three in the semifinal
playoff game versus Carolina, but had only one assist"
all season. He will need to pass more if this line is to
be successful against Hopkins' stronger opponents.
Chanenchuk will be breaking into the top two midfields after playing infrequently on the third line and
for many clears last season. Said Zimmerman,
"Chanenchuk is one of the niftiest players, but is
relatively new to playing midfield. He needs to continue to improve on defense." A Farmingdale, New
York product, Chanenchuk will probably play on the
same line with former high school teammate
Krumenacker, which should help him all around. To
be successful, however, he will need to improve on his
shot, which is somewhat weak.
While Castle did not play much during the second
half of the 1984 season, he will also be on one of the
top two lines. A quick and extremely fast middie with
a very hard outside shot, Castle will pose a threat to
any defense. He should be especially helpful against
zones, where his shot will keep the Jays' opponents
honest.
Crawford continues in much the same capacity as
last year, when he impressed many Hopkins fans with
his all-out play on the third midfield line. This
sophomore had only one goal and assist, but netted
12 groundballs. "Jack gives 100 percent all the time,"
said Zimmerman. "He's relentless and does the things
you need him to do. He's going to play."
John Dressel, a two-time high school All-America,

is the second third line member.The Lawrenceville product has had an average pre-season, but "possesses
a wealth of ability," according to Zimmerman. He
may see extra action on clears.
Rzempoluch is the newest member of the Farmingdale Connection. He will team with Crawford and
Dressel on the third line and may face-off occasionally.
Stewart will play occasionally and may also faceoff. He had a good fall, according to Zimmerman,and
has worked hard preparing for the season.
Diorio will also play infrequently, though his role
may change as the season progresses. When he does
see action it will probably be on clears.
Webster is a walk-on and this will be his first season
with the team.
One of the biggest factors in Hopkins' last two
championship games was ball control off the faceoffs.
In 1983, Syracuse dominated late in the game and was
able to launch its tremendous comeback. Last year, Hopkins jumped out to an early lead as it won nearly
every faceoff in the first quarter, and held off Syracuse
later on as the faceoff unit retained control of the ball.
This season, the Blue Jays will be even stronger as
they return all three of their specialists, Greg Matthews, Lee Davidson and Glenn Fidje, and add potential depth with middies Joe Rzempoluch and Damon
Stewart.
Matthews took the majority of faceoffs last season
(64 percent) and dominated in almost every game, winning just over three-fifths of them. He also had 84
groundballs and won the Ciccarone Ground Ball
Award for his efforts. This was a vast improvement
over the 1983 season when he had a modest 55. The
senior can only improve this year, and if his progress
is as dramatic as last year, he may dominate totally.
Davidson saw considerable action as well, taking a
quarter of the faceoffs and winning over 64 percent,
best on the team. He also scored four goals and added an assist while scooping up 35 groundballs. Davidson will most likely be Matthews' main challenger for
the number one position.
Fidge didn't see much action, facing-off only 30
times, but he did win 63 percent and grabbed-up 14
groundballs. He will have to work hard to beat out
his teammates.

MIDFIELD
If you subscribe to the theory that games are won
at midfield, you'll be happy to know that the middies
comprise Hopkins' strongest unit and are probably-the
best midfields in the nation. This is largely the result
of the Jays' small losses and their typically strong
recruiting effort. Hopkins lost only three players from
this unit as honorable mention All-America John
Tucker and Rich Glancy were graduated, and
freshman Tom Engelke transferred to Nassau County Junior College.
Returning for the Blue Jays are first team AllAmerica and Division I Midfielder of the Year Del
Dressel and second team All-America John
Krumenacker from the starting line, and juniors Steve
Mutscheller and Chris Schreiber from the second line.
The Jays also return seniors Glenn Fidje, Lee Davidson, and Greg Matthews, junior Dave Castle, and
sophomores Bruce Chanenchuk, Jack Crawford,
Damon Stewart, and Joe Diorio. New players include
sophomore Mike Webster and freshman recruits Joe
Rzempoluch and John Dressel.
Del Dressel is generally regarded as the best midfielder on the squad, having been, by far, the highest
scoring middie for the last two years. He has also been
very consistent, netting 27 goals each year with an
average of 18 assists. Additionally, Dressel has been
a veritable ball hog, scooping up 59 groundballs last
season while taking well over 100 shots. Perhaps his
greatest asset, though, is his ability to lead the transition fast breaks and to score when the team needs
a goal. This season, Dressel should continue to
dominate at midfield, as he takes one step closer
toward becoming only the third four-time first team
All-American in collegiate lacrosse history.
The second big gun in this unit is tri-captain
Krumenacker. Despite having a somewhat disappointing season offensively in 1984, Zimmerman is confident in this senior's talents and his ability to bounce
back to peak form. "John does a great job defensively and is very good at setting up the other players,"
said Zimmerman. "He just needs to concentrate at
putting the ball on net." In addition, nobody on the
team executes the clear as well as Krumenacker,
especially against the tough riders such as North
Carolina. Should "Boomer" regain his accuracy, he
will undoubtedly fill opponents' nets this season.

pend to a large extent on Matricciani's ability to keep

well," and his continually improving, consistent play
should help solidify the defensive unit.

school midfielder, McLam has the speed and ability
to lead a fast break upfield as he dished out two assists
last season. He also raked in 17 groundballs. "McLam
did an outstanding job last year on the rope," said ,

A three-sport letterman, Mitchell will again be on

Mitchell collected 16 groundballs last year, and with
his strengths of speed and size, this sophomore should
contribute greatly towards the defense's success.

The Game of Lacrosse
U

Lacrosse, in its original form, was widely played by
North American Indians as early as the 1600's. It was
described in accounts by European settlers, who
observed unruly competitions among hundreds of
competitors which lasted from many hours to many
days. The game was to the Indians a source of recreation and a means of preparation of warriors.
Lacrosse today has incorporated the essentials of a
good spectator sport. Its principles are basic: Two
teams of ten players each compete on an open field
110 yards long, with the object of shooting a hard rubber ball into the opposing net. The restrictions which
make the game unique are that a player may only control the ball by maneuvering it with a large stick capped by a small net(although the ball may also be kicked). Armed with this weapon, the player can pass,
bounce, and shoot the ball with remarkable accuracy.
The game itself lasts 60 minutes on the college level,
with stoppage of play for goals, penalties, and outof-bounds. Penalties include the following: offsides,
violated when a team has fewer than three men on the
offensive side of the field or fewer than four on the
defensive side; crease violations; unsportsmanlike conduct; and rough play violations, including pushing,
slashing, and illegal checking.
Among the ten men on the field, three attackmen
remain on the offensive half of the field, three
defensemen occupy the defensive half, and three midfielders traverse the entire field. The goalie directly
guards the goal and is provided with a circular crease
which the opposing team may not enter.
Strict restrictions are placed on the sticks, which are
limited in material and dimensions. Illegal sticks draw
severe penalties.
Rules concerning possession in lacrosse are different
'than many other sports. Turnovers occur when a ball
in one team's possession is lost out of bounds or when
a penalty occurs. Another rule unique to lacrosse states
that a shot on goal which goes out of bounds is given
to the player that was closest to the ball when it left
the field.
Lacrosse is a game which is constantly in motion.,
The officials attempt to keep the game moving as
quickly as possible by starting the clock as soon as the
ball is ready. A game will last two hours or more
Without a boring moment.

The idea of a special lacrosse insert was born in
the fall when it was decided that the national champion Blue Jays should receive some of the coverage
they deserve. The result is this special issue, which
is, to our knowledge, the most extensive of its kind
in News-Letter history. "Lacrosse '85" would not
exist, however, were it not for the assistance of
many people.
We thank Coaches Don Zimmerman and Roy
Simmons, Jr., for their help in our coverage of each
of their teams. Jerry Shifflett of "In the Crease"
provided scores of photographs for our use. We
especially thank Mr. Don Fritz for his gracious efforts in recalling a bygone era.
We are most indebted, however, to the members
of the News-Letter staff for their tireless assistance.
Editor Eileen Fitzgerald and Managing Editor
Kathrin Engisch were supportive throughout. We
thank Maria Mitchell, Sharon Fischman, and Brad
Handler for their technichal assistance. Larry Volz
and Jess Bunshaft donated valuable time for the
photography.
We are grateful to our contributors Craig Caplan
and Adam Warner for their skill and punctuality,
to Skip Collins for his sleepless hours, and to
Gregory King and Mary Ginder for their constant
enthusiasm.
Finally, we would like to thank Chuck Maute,
Business Manager, Tammy Huck, Production
Manager, and David Epstein, reporter extraordinaire. Without their time, effort, and dedication,
this issue would be a shell of what it is.

Howard Bregman

David Brengel

by David Brengel

Returning in the goal is All-Everything Larry Quinn.
The spectactular play of this senior tri-captain last
season is generally regarded as the reason Hopkins won
the national championship. Another strong year by
Quinn could be all the edge the Blue Jays need to
repeat.
It is interesting to note that the last four times
Hopkins has had a first team All-American in the goal
(Mike Federico - 1978-80; Quinn - 1984) it has won
the national title. It is also interesting that the previous
two recipients of first team All-America in the goal
Sears, North Carolina - 1982; George Slabowski, Army-1983) were juniors and were unable to repeat
the tollowing year.
William Tierney will join the Blue Jay coaching staff
for the first time after spending the last several years
at the helm of the Rochester Institute of Technology
lacrosse team. Tierney won the 1984 Division III
Coach of the Year award as RIT made the playoffs
for the first time. Tierney will work with the goalies,
midfielders and the man-down defense.
Returning assistant coaches Jerry Pfeifer and Fred
Smith will guide the defense and Joe Devlin, the offense. Dennis Townsend works with the attackmen and
defensemen individually, and Joe Cowan instructs the
extra-man offensive unit.
With their most difficult schedule in decades, the
Blue Jays must concentrate on consistent play and not
take any opponent lightly. "Every team on our
schedule has the potential to beat us," says Zimmerman,"if we're not mentally and physically prepared.
We looked at the practice schedule and targeted areas
to work on early this year to avoid inconsistent play.
If we have a good attitude, work hard and stay
physically sound, I'm confident of our chances."

ATTACK

All-America attackman Brian Wood

The Blue Jay attack unit appears to be solid this year
despite the loss to graduation of starters Peter Scott
(first team All-America) and Captain Willy Odenthal
(third team All-America), Brent Ciccarone, and Eric
Dressel. The team returns second team All-America
Brian Wood and fourth man Craig Bubier, as well as
Clark Thielemann and Bill Single. In addition, Coach
Zimmerman has added Geoff Nordberg and two
highly talented freshman recruits, Mike Morrill and
John Ciccarone.
Wood was the third leading scorer for Hopkins last
year, both in goals and total points, and should be the
hub of this year's attack. As the attackman with the
most game experience, Wood is expected by Zimmerman to be the "quarterback on the attack," with the
team looking to him "to anchor the unit." Wood
needs to become a more reliable scorer, though, and
his ability or inability to play consistently will have major ramifications for the team.
Outside of the added responsibility of leading the
attack, this sophomore's role should change little. He
will be positioned primarily to one side of the goal,
usually about ten yards out, looking either to drive

towards the goal or to quickly release a shot. Either
way, fans can expect Wood to have the ball often and
to score 25-30 goals this season.
Bubier will join Wood as a definite starter. Zimmerman describes Bubier as "a power attackman who'll
go one-on-one a lot." Additionally, he'll probably
emerge as the unit's primary feeder, although his exact role may depend on who Zimmerman plays at the
third attack position. Tall and agile, Bubier seems a
natural to play behind the goal, but he has added
enough muscle to also hold his own in the crease area.
Last year, Bubier tallied six goals and five assists
despite limited playing time. With his ability to cut
quickly to the net and a hard turn-around shot, this
sophomore's ,mbers should more than double this
year.
Rounding out the starting unit at the crease position should be Single, who has the notable distinction
of having scored on 80 percent of his shots over the
last two years. While he has tallied only four times,
including three last year, the figure is an indication of

The Johns Hopkins Blue Jays enter the 1985 season
as defending champions and the pre-season favorites,
and each game will be a true test of their ability. From
start to finish, the Jays must face the top teams in Prediction: Hopkins 13, Syracuse 11
lacrosse in their quest to retain the title. The following is a game-by-game analysis of this year's Blue Jay
Manhasset, N.Y.
schedule and a look at some other top teams' HOBART

Historical Series: Blue Jays lead, 2-0

A reminder that all Blue Jay games can be heard on
WJHU, 88.1 FM.

Each year, lacrosse fans talk about why Hobart is
not a Division I team, and how they would fare if they
were. And each year, the Statesmen receive a chance
to prove themselves when they face the Division I
champs in the now traditional Day of Champions
game on Long Island.
Hobart has dominated Division III lacrosse, winning the NCAA championship the last five years. They
have not always done well against Division I schools,
however, losing to such non-notables as C.W. Post.
Still, the Statesmen can play among the best, as
evidenced by their 1983 victory over North Carolina,
which ended the Tar Heels' 26-game winning streak.
The Statesmen are led by attackmen Mark Van
Arsdale (32 goals, 28 assists in 1984) and Tom
Grimaldi(26 goals, 19 assists). Grimaldi was voted the
outstanding attackman in Division III in 1984 while
Van Arsdale was named Hobart's offensive player of
the year. In the midfield, losses to graduation will leave
the Statesmen weakened substantially. First team AllAmericans Jim Holihan (13 goals, 10 assists) and Pat
O'Hara (14 goals, 4 assists) are both gone from the
defending champions' roster.
Defensively, the Statesmen feature second team AllAmerica Dan Whelan on the close defense and junior
goalie Chuck Warren, the MVP of the 1984 championship game against Washington College. The defense,
however, was only able to hold opponents to 122 goals
over 13 games in 1984.
Clearly Hobart has less to lose in this game, and this
makes for a dangerous opponent for Hopkins. The
Blue Jays have to be prepared to play all out.
Prediction: Hopkins 12, Hobart 9

Homewood Field
SYRACUSE
2:00 p.m.
Saturday, March 9
Historical Series: Blue Jays lead, 9-2
Most sports rivalries take time to develop and then
build over many years. This rivalry formed after all
of one game. The intensity of the 1983 comeback victory by Syracuse in the championship game was only
equalled by last year's rematch at Delaware, where the
Blue Jays captured the title. Many lacrosse enthusiasts
are viewing this contest as the rubber game of this
match-up, although it is likely that the two teams will
meet again in the NCAA tournament.
The Orangemen's losses to graduation were
minimal, and their young defense has gained valuable
experience. (For more detail, see the Syracuse team
report.) For those fans who have been asleep for the
past two years, Syracuse relies on an explosive offense
which can strike at any time, usually in bunches. In
this way, the Orangemen are never really out of a game
until time becomes a factor.
The Syracuse defense is not overly strong, and
Hopkins has had little difficulty in scoring against it,
with 29 goals in the '83 and '84 finals. However, the
Jays must limit Syracuse's offensive opportunities by
using ball control and taking the Orangemen out of
their game. Syracuse. has too much firepower to only
concentrate on stopping a Tim Nelson or a Brad Kotz.
There are numerous elements involved in this game,
and any one of them could be the deciding factor. Will
there be a key injury, as there has been in the previous
two years? What about playing conditions? Cold
weather will likely translate into less scoring, which
would tend to favor Hopkins.
The Blue Jays need solid defense, a lot of which
depends upon Larry Quinn's performance. An
outstanding game by Quinn, which is more than a
common occurrence, could tilt the balance. Also, the
attitude of Syracuse coming in will depend a great deal
upon their previous game against North Carolina.
In truth, with two such excellent teams, the deciding
factor is usually desire. Syracuse wants to avenge last

attackmen. On top of this, head coach Terry Corcoran
had an outstanding recruiting year.
The Blue Jays must avoid any complacency. This
game is being played within ten days of the Syracuse
and Hobart contest, and Hopkins may be a little tired.
A lack of intensity could lead to some unpleasant
results. However, Don Zimmerman is too good a head
coach to allow this to happen.
Prediction: Hopkins 10, Washington College 6

Homewood Field
PRINCETON
2:00 p.m.
Saturday, March 23
Historical Series: Blue Jays lead, 39-12
Princeton is usually a solid all-around team, and
they are always well-prepared by head coach Jerry
Schmidt. This year, the Tigers are looking to rebound
from a 2-12 season in 1984.
Defensively, the Tigers return their starting goalie,
Chris Corcoran, but they have lost their entire close
defense, with the exception of All-American Jerry Rizzieri. On offense, the outlook is brighter, with four
midfielders and the entire attack returning. The offensive threats for the tigers include senior attackmen Jon
Lurie(18 goals, 5 assists) and Charlie Stillwell(5 goals,
16 assists.)

If you attended last year's meeting between these
two teams, it's hard not to laugh when you think about
it. The Blue Jays played one of the best quarters of
lacrosse ever witnessed at Homewood in building an
amazing 15-0 lead on their way to coasting to a 21-10
embarrassment of the Scarlet Knights.
That's what makes this year's contest so intruiging.
The 1984 game was a result of several factors. Rutgers
had played Syracuse to a close 15-12 decision only a
few days prior to that game, and actually arrived at
Homewood only an hour and a half before the starting time. They were understandably a little flat.
Hopkins, on the other hand, was well-prepared and
came out on fire, which led to the one-sidedness of
the scoring.
What happens in 1985 depends more on Rutgers
than it does on Hopkins. Despite what you may
believe, Rutgers is for real. The Scarlet Knights suffered some losses, most notably of their top attackman
Bill Naslonski. But they return standout goalie John
Naslonski and most of their defense and midfield.
What may be most important is that Rutgers returns
with an extra year's experience. To witness the results,
one need go no further than looking at the Knights'
9-3 defeat of Syracuse in the fall. And while it was only
fall ball, it has certainly boosted Rutger's confidence.
Rutgers fields a young but very talented team.
Against Hopkins last year, they employed three different longstick units, and they returned eight of the
nine members. Throughout the lineup they have quality players; the Scarlet Knights may soon be ready to
break into the upper echelon of college lacrosse.
An important factor in this year's game is that once
again, Rutgers will face Syracuse and Hopkins consecutively on the road. The outcome of the Hopkins
game, therefore, will depend upon the results of the
Syracuse contest.
The real reason that this game depends so much

upon Rutgers, though, is last year's game. The
memory of that crushing defeat will be ever present.
This will lead to one of two results. Rutgers can use
that defeat in a positive way, to fire themelves up for
a revenge match, or they could be haunted by it, and
expect the same to happen again this year. The former
will lead to a good game, the latter to another blowout.
Rutgers has a fine coaching staff, so they will undoubtedly be more prepared this year. Still, as long
as the Blue Jays are also prepared, they should come
away with a win.

12LAX/MARCH 8, 1985

A small but skillful class

Five Freshman Give '85 Jays A Dose of Talent
by Adam Warner
The 1985 season marks the first year that players
recruited by Don Zimmerman as head coach will put
on the Blue Jay uniform. Only five freshmen join the
squad from the class of '88, but all five were high
school consensus • All-Americans in their senior
seasons. Though it is unlikely that any will make as
big an impact this year as Brian Wood did as a frosh
in '84, before they graduate they should prove to be
as good as any other class of recent memory. If
nothing else, three of the five have names and family
ties quite familiar to Blue Jay loyalists: Ciccarone,
Morrill, and Dressel.
The first is John Ciccarone, son of Henry Ciccarone, Sr., who preceded Zimmerman as Hopkins'
head coach, and brother of former Blue Jay stars Brent
and Henry, Jr. Like Brent, John plays attack, and in
•high school he was truly exceptional. He was a four
year varsity player at Boys Latin in Baltimore, and in
the words of his former coach Bobby Shriver,"he just
got better and better every year. Last year, he had what
I'd call a truly outstanding season."
The team had a fine year as well, as they made it
to the area finals, where they lost 8-6 to a Loyola team
that they had beaten six days earlier. According to
Shriver, "If we had won that game, Ciccarone would
have been named Metro Player of the Year."
Shriver is also quick to praise Ciccarone's intensity
toward the game. "He'll work as hard as anyone you'll
see. He's been lifting weights in order to bulk up for
his college career. He has all the tools to be an excellent
player."
It seems as if the only problem that Ciccarone may
have is his size. At 5'10" and 160 lbs., he is by no
means tiny, but in major college ball he will be facing
big defensemen every game, and that may get tough.
Also joining the attack is Mike Morrill, a third
generation Blue Jay. His grandfather, Kelso, played
for Hopkins in the 1920's, while his father, Bill, was
a star in the early 1960's.

If any frosh is to play a big role in Hopkins' national championship defense, it will likely be Morrill.
He has the size at 6'0", 185 lbs., excellent skills and
of course, the genes. In the scrimmage against Penn,
he led Hopkins with three goals.
Morrill played his high school ball at St. Paul's in
Brooklandville for George Mitchell, himself a former
Blue Jay as well as the father of defenseman Steve
Mitchell.
The new Dressel is John Dressel, brother of the better known Del. John will also play midfield, although
the two will not team on the same line.
A Baltimore native, John starred for Lawrenceville
Prep in New .,:rsey. Though he only played there for
one season, his coach Marshall Chambers ranks him
among the best players he's had; one who helped his
program immensely. Particularly impressive were his
stick skills, which Chambers called "the very best I've
seen it this level of play."
At Lawrenceville, Dressel played on attack, "mainly
because we had.some fast midfielders," says
Chambers. "Besides," he adds, "it was better having
him on the field more often."
In analyzing •Dressel's future as a Blue Jay,
Chambers sees no problems down the road. "Here,
we lacked a whole team to surround him, but at
Hopkins he'll be playing with nine other excellent
players."
Hopkins' other midfield recruit is Joe Rzempoluch.
He hails from Farmingdale High School on Long
Island, a virtual factory that has also produced current Hopkins stars John Krumenacker, John DeTommaso and Bruce Chanenchuk.
Right now, Rzempoluch may be the best prepared
of his class to move into a key position. At 6'0", 190
lbs., he has the size, and coming from Farmingdale
he was brought up in a style of play similar to that
of Hopkins. Harntranft, his high school coach,
believes that Joe will "fit in very well to Coach Zimmerman's system. Here, like at Hopkins, midfielders
bring the ball up very quickly on offense, while they

are all required to play excellent defense." Rzempoluch
particularly excelled at the defensive phase of the
position.
Aside from being named All-America, Rzempoluch
won the Jim Brown Award as the area's best midfielder. Yes, it's THE Jim Brown. As for Farmingdale,
they finished their year at 17-2, the number one seed
in their region before being upset in the playoffs.
Last, but not least, Hopkins brought in Jeff Kramer,
a goalie. Kramer attended Worthington High School
in Ohio, as he is the only player on the squad this year
not to come from an Atlantic state.
Though highly talented, Kramer will not see much
action at all this year in the nets. All three goalies from
1984 return, including NCAA tournament MVP Larry
Quinn, who is unquestionably the best goalie in the
country. The 5'10", 160 lb. freshman will get his big
chance next year, when he will battle sophomore Stuart
Jones and any other newcomers for the starting slot.

The Sieve Story
If you've been wondering what those strange people with kitchen utensils have been doing at lacrosse
games, you need not wonder any more. They're sieves.
No, not the people, the utensils. The tradition actually began at Cornell hockey games. The chant of
"sieve" is directed at the opposition's goalie, hoping
that he will let pucks(or in our case lacrosse balls) pass
through, as a sieve allows objects to pass through.
When done effectively, it has been known to rattle
many a goaltender.
The tradition was brought to Hopkins by two
students, Mark Lazarus and David Epstein, for the
1983 playoff game between Hopkins and Cornell.
Sieves can be purchased at any food store for a small
price. Colanders and other sorts of strainers are acceptable, but they're not the genuine article. So, get
yourself a sieve, head out to the game, and abuse the
other team's goalie.

An Interview with Coach Roy Simmons, Jr.
The coach of the Orange discusses his teams, Hopkins, and the future.
Editor's Note: Roy Simmons, Jr., the head coach of the
Syracuse lacrosse team, spoke with Howard Bregman and
David Epstein of the News-Letter on February 21st. We thank
Coach Simmonsfor his time and his help with our coverage
of the Orangemen.

N-L: Could you sum up the team's attitude going into the game with Hopkins? Is the outlook different
after having been in the finals for two years?
Simmons: Well, we don't play Hopkins normally in
the regular season. We've played in the playoffs, and
stubbed their toe. It's important to get a shot at
Hopkins and not have to wait until May, if that's a
possibility at all. ..Of course, we start off up here with
North Carolina on the fifth of March, so I think that
that puts the Blue Jays second; we're thinking more
about the Tar Heels right now, we know that that game
will be very important.
N-L: So you'll be travelling right after the Carolina
game by bus?
Simmons: Yes, we're going to come down the night
of the seventh, so we'll be there for two nights. We'll
have a workout on the eighth; but we'll arrive in
Baltimore on the night of the seventh. That's two days
after our Carolina game.
N-L: Everybody knows that Kotz and Nelson are now
seniors. Tom Nims is back in the goal, and you have
a lot of good young players, several of whom really
shone in the 1984 championship game. Do you think
that this is the strongest team you've fielded in the past
four years?
Simmons: Well, I think it's as strong as last year, and
as strong as the year before. In '83, we had a lot of
sophomores. Now much of the team this year are
seniors. We're returning our entire defense; the unit
was really young last year.. . Our midfield lost David
Desko to graduation, who had three goals in the title
game. It's a big loss, but it will be filled in...Our close
attack is intact. We'll feel the absence of Randy Lundblad, who had a great career here, and a great season
last year. Tommy Nelson, who filled in for his brother
in the finals, will be back. We also have Tom Korrie.
So we look very good on paper.

of personalities. They gear a lot of their practices to

and not rely on our attack exclusively. We realize that
they can be tied up pretty tight. We don't have any
preconceived plan to play an attack-oriented offense.
You know, the bad thing last year when our big gun
got hurt, that phase of our game was wiped out, and
we had to adjust, so we've learned the hard way that
you can't depend on any one person. God forbid
another bad injury, but he may be healthy but shut

dominated by one unit.

Simmons: Well, lacrosse at Syracuse is looked at differently than at Hopkins. It is the sport there, and
