THE LACROSSE NEWS MAGAZINE

LACROSSE '85/15LAX

Orangeman Lacrosse:

Steve Parker: Syracuse SI

by David Epstein
In order to build a top college lacrosse program, a
school must have a strong high school recruiting base.
Logic would therefore dictate that the wider the
recruiting area, the more talent that would be available
and therefore the more successful the program. Under
this assumption, the Syracuse lacrosse team has
managed to defy logic.
For the past half decade, two teams have dominated
New York state high school lacrosse. Downstate,
Yorktown High School (Westchester County) has
reached the state final in five consecutive years, capturing the title in 1984. In doing so, each year
Yorktown has had to defeat the top team on Long
Island.
Upstate, West Genesee High has been so dominant,
that it borders on the unbelievable. The Wildcats have
been to the state finals the last four years, winning
three times. Along the way, they tied a state record
by winning an astounding 91 consecutive games, a
streak which was broken in last year's state finals by
Yorktown.
Not surprisingly, these two schools have consistently
turned out top players and more than their share of
All-Americans. What is surprising is that Syracuse has
been able to build a championship program basically
around players from these two high schools. Syracuse
Head Coach Roy Simmons, Jr. is quick to deny this
idea, and he points out that his team has players from
Maryland and Massachusetts. However, the
undeniable evidence is that eight of the Orangemen's
ten starters, and over one third of the team, are from
either West Genesee or Yorktown. Of course, this
means that there are also many Syracuse players from
other areas; many top players from both West Genny
and Yorktown have opted to attend other colleges.
Still, Simmons has used the emergence of lacrosse in
Westchester and Central New York to his advantage
as no other coach has been able to do.
For Syracuse, this has translated into two consecutive championship caliber teams. The 1983 team
was victorious in the finals, the 1984 team was the
runner-up, and both times they faced Hopkins. Unfortunately for the rest of lacrosse, the 1985 Syracuse
squad may be their strongest ever.
The Syracuse style of play is to use a highly potent
offense and an unspectacular defense to outscore their
Opponents. They often have trouble in tight defensive
games, but almost always win a shutout. The
Orangemen's ability to score is almost uncanny, and
When they score a goal, there are usually two or three
more to follow. It is this type of streak scoring that
has characterized the Syracuse team, and, not surpris-

Syracuse at a Glance

ingly, it is a trademark
of the West Genesee
High team also.
The main force behind
Syracuse's scoring ability
is their attackmen, who
last year accounted for
149 (or 55%) of the
team's 262 goals. This
year's unit is already being considered the most potent attack in the country. It
consists, not surprisingly, of one
player from West Genesee and two from
Yorktown.
The leading attackman for Syracuse is senior
Tim Nelson (Yorktown). All Nelson has done in
his two years at Syracuse (his freshman year was
spent at N.C. State) is amass 186 points, being
named to the first team All-America squad and winning the Turnbull Trophy as outstanding Division I attackman both years. Nelson plays behind the goal and
literally runs the offense, using his accurate passing
ability to pile up assists at an incredible pace. He was
injured in the championship game last year, and is
reported to be one hundred percent after surgery and
rehabilitation. Although he will be wearing a brace
during the season, it is not likely that it will affect his
play.
With a Tim Nelson behind the goal, one might think
that all the other attackman need do is be the recipient
of Tim's passes, simply pumping in the goals. And in
one case, this is not far from the truth. Junior Tom
Korrie, out of West Genesee, piled up 51 goals last
season on his way to earning third team All-America
honors. A fine player in his own right, Korrie thrived
on Nelson's passing ability in his becoming Syracuse's
leading scorer last year. In light of this, what perhaps
could be considered less than all-around play on Korrie's part makes him no less dangerous.
The third attackman, sophomore Tom Nelson, may
best be known as Tim's younger brother, although he
came into prominence last year in the championship
game by scoring 3 goals after replacing brother Tim.
This year, Tom will be filling the spot vacated by the
graduation of Randy Lundblad. What people may
soon observe, though, is that Tom Nelson may be the
best all-around attackman on the team. He may not
pile up the statistics that others will(though he did have
21 goals and 16 assists in limited duty last season), but
he can play the crease, scoop up ground balls, hit, feed
and score. In sum, he is a dedicated, total player. Tom
becomes all the more dangerous teamed with Tim, who
he has practiced and played with for most of his life.
If that were not enough depth at attack, junior Emmett Printup is available in case of injury or just to
give someone a rest. Printup had a hat-trick in last
year's finals and received recognition for his play in
the World Lacrosse Competition held at Los Angeles.
Clearly, in order to stop Syracuse, one must stop their
attack—all of their attack.

Turning to the midfield, Syracuse may actually be
slightly weaker than in the past two years. Key losses
for the Orange include second team All-America Dave
Desko and face-off man Mark Burnam. Still, the first
midfield unit should be among the best in lacrosse.
Leading the top line is two-time first team AllAmerica and 1983 Player of the Year Brad Kotz(West
Genesee). Kotz faces off for that line with mixed
results, but more importantly, he can ignite the team
at any moment, as evidenced by his 31 goals and 30
assists last season. Kotz is clearly the line's leader as
well as being its best player.
The second member of the first line, Todd Curry,
is also from West Genesee. Curry, a sophomore,
became a member of the first midfield as a freshman.
While he is not as prolific a scorer as a Kotz, his outside shot is among the best around. Last season he had
11 goals, but you can rest assured that most of them
were bullets.
The second midfield will be led by sophomore Pat
Donahue, that line's face-off man. He will most likely be joined by John Schimoler, a senior who had a
solid season in 1984. The third spot will be filled by
a player yet to be determined, depending upon early
play against Carolina and Hopkins. Coach Simmons
will use these games to establish a definite line for the
rest of the year.

In any case, there will likely be a great disparity between the first and second midfield lines. While the first
midfield accounted for 47 goals and 39 assists last
season, the second midfield (depending upon its third
member) will have tallied last year, no more than 19
goals with just 6 assists. Because of this, the second
line becomes more of a supplement to the high
powered attack than a dangerous unit of its own.
Syracuse returns their close defense intact, and the
added year of experience should be a big plus. Junior
Kevin Sheehan was a third team All-America last
season, and this year he will lead the defense as a team
co-captain. Joining Sheehan will be another junior and
honorable mention All-America, Jeff Desko (West
Genesee),as well as sophomore Mike O'Donnell
(Yorktown). The three play well as a unit, but still cannot compare with other top defenses. It remains to be
seen how well they will have progressed from last year.
Experience on defense can mean a lot, and the difference could be significant. The rope defense of Dan
Pratt, Fred Opie and Chris Burt should see some action, although Simmons does not plan to overly rely
on the unit.
The Syracuse goalie will once again be Tom Nims.
Nims, a senior from West Genesee, was named
honorable mention All-America in 1984. He is not a
spectacular goalie, but plays solidly throughout the
season. Like most goalies, though, if he becomes hot,
he can be tough to penetrate. Syracuse is also fortunate
to have a top backup goalie in Tom Gygory, a junior
out of Annapolis. Simmons will probably not hesitate
to use him should the situation call for it.
In sum, the Syracuse team is much like those of the
recent past. They will rely heavily on the attack and
first midfield for some high scoring, while hoping that
the second midfield and defense can hold their own.
But the key to this year's team could be experience.
The defense has played together for a full year, and
the only real newcomer to the first string is Frank
Lanuto, and he is a senior. Also, players such as Tim
Nelson, Brad Kotz and Tom Nims are seniors, and will
be hungry for a championship in their final year. This
desire may be Syracuse's most potent weapon of all.

16LAX/MARCH 8, 1985

The Championship Teams of '50 and '84: A
Separated by 34 years, the two squads represent
When making such a comparison, a complete
perspective is required. One must examine all four
years of each team's existence: 1981-1984 and
1947-1950.
A comparison of teams or, for that matter, players
of different eras is a delicate undertaking. In the case
of these two magnificent squads, fortunately, most of
the participants are still with us. The author is one of
those people who feel that lacrosse is a sport that
makes an enthusiast's liver curl with enjoyment. I am
of the opinion that the nuances and intricacies of the
game demand more knowledge than most other sports;
I am privileged to have witnessed the majority .of
games each team played. Therefore, I shall state facts,
cite quotations, and let the reader form his own
opinion.
Bill Tanton, sports editor of the Evening Sun, stated
in a recent article, "Actually, the 1950 team, as
everyone calls it, was four teams, from 1947-1950.
Many argue they were the best four teams in the
university's history, and if they were, the 1948 squad
probably would have to rank immediately behind the
1950 team on the all-time list. That was the final year
for Brooke Tunstall and Ray Greene, two of the best
ever to play for the Jays."
Due to conditions created by wartime, both Tunstall
and Greene earned first team All-America lacrosse .
honors at two different universities, the former at Cornell and Hopkins, the latter at Drexel and Hopkins.
Many knowledgeable lacrosse personalities familiar
with Hopkins teams over 60 years were interviewed by
Tanton concerning their choice of JHU's greatest
teams. These were analyzed and finally released a few
years ago by the one-time News-Letter sports editor
and Hopkins varsity player. He continues to rate the
squad of 1950 as his top team in Johns Hopkins
history.

"The 1984 team is much stronger
and quicker. They work with weights
and can probably bench-press 75 or 100
pounds more than we could."
-Wilson Fewster
The success of the two teams is self-evident. The
1950 team members felt good about themselves and
in turn produced brilliant results. They played and won
31 consecutive intercollegiate games over four years,
losing only 4 games to club teams. The 1984 squad won
14 intercollegiate games, or almost half that amount,
in one year. No play-off system existed in 1950, nor
were mid-week games played.
The game itself has changed much in the 34 years
that separate these teams. A momentous disparity exists in the physical equipment used. Besides basic
athletic shoes, padding, and jerseys, each 1950 player
carried a wooden stick with a gut wall and a leather
and gut strung net. These sticks were usually made by
Indians in Canada. Since then, a quantum leap forward in the technology of lacrosse sticks has been
made. All male players today use a hollow aluminumhandled stick with a synthetic plastic double-walled
head strung with nylon cord netting. These modern
factory-manufactured sticks are perfectly balanced.
The old wooden ones seldom were. Experts claim the
ball tends to settle in the modern-type nets more readily
than in the old gut and leather type.
The late, legendary Frenchy Julien, closely
associated with lacrosse for 60 years, commented, "I
cannot understand how a player can miss catching a
ball with today's equipment."
In 1950 all games were played on natural grass. Today, most games are played on astroturf. A bouncing
ball becomes predictable. Many old-timers recall
scooping a net full of mud to retrieve a ball.
An obvious dissimilarity relates to substitutions. The
1950 squad ran midfields as units into games, replacing one unit for another to catch its breath. Coaching
philosophy in 1984 has changed in sophistication.
There are more specialists today. For example, a
center, once he gains possession after a face-off, will

frequently be individually replaced. Also, as a defensive strategy, long-handled midfield sticks are used.
Glancing at programs of the two periods, major differences in personnel are obvious. All of the participants but one on the 1950 team were from the
Baltimore metropolitan area. In 1984, the majority of
players hailed from outside Baltimore. The secondary
school graduates of the three major hot-beds of
lacrosse, Baltimore, upper New York state, and Long
Island, presently have a larger selection of lacrosseplaying colleges to attend.
The vast majority of the lacrosse team in 1950, with
little or no inducement, voluntarily attended Johns
Hopkins. In 1984, recruiting high school lacrosse talent
is the norm for most colleges and universities that are
serious about the sport. In 1950, exactly half of the
players were service veterans and they received monthly subsistence checks. Most native Baltimoreans lived
at home.
Karl Levy, captain of the 1926 team, who continues
to attend Hopkins games, once stated, "The 1950 team
was the best I have seen. Those fellows in 1950 had
a certain maturity because their college had been
delayed by the war. They were men, not boys. The
1984 team was a surprisingly great team. They were
clever and showed much finesse. The game today is
much smoother and more graceful."
"Karl Levy might well make a case for his own 1926
team which was 9-0 and gave up only 11 goals," wrote
Bill Tanton. "But the 1950 squad was so deep in talent
stockpiled after World War II that we shall never again
see anything like it."
In 1984, the G.I. Bill, as we knew it is no more.

"I believe the 1950squad contained
better all-around athletes because most
of us played other sports. We had a
superior close defense."
-Tom Gough
Tuition, room, and board are now major factors when
a talented lacrosse player considers college. Hopkins,
in order to compete with universities granting hill
scholarships, found it necessary some years ago to adjust its athletic philosophy. The university's commitment to pure amateurism in intercollegiate sports continues largely unchanged. Full athletic scholarships are
not awarded to Hopkins students. All athletes must
meet the University's admission requirements. Limited
financial aid is available; if there is a need, Johns
Hopkins will listen.
Furthermore, an athlete at Hopkins is presently
penalized due to NCAA regulations pertaining to

financial aid. An athlete receiving scholarship aid in
lacrosse, a Division I sport at Hopkins, cannot participate in a Division III sport such as football. Only
two members of the 1984 lacrosse team, due to the arrangement of their aid, were able to play another sport.
Almost half of the 1950 team participated in two or

"I cannot understand how a player
can miss catching a ball with today's
equipment."
-Frenchy Julien
There are lacrosse players today with the necessary
academic credentials attending Hopkins because that
is where they wish to go. The same situation existed
in 1950. Because there are considerably more secondary schools playing lacrosse today in many areas of
the country than there were in 1950, there exists a
greater quantity of good quality lacrosse talent.
The convenience of modern athletics also separates
these two teams. When Hopkins played Princeton in
1950, for example, the team bus would leave early
Saturday morning to travel to Princeton. After their
arrival, players would get dressed, warm up, play the
game, and then return to Baltimore the same day. In
1984, the team left on a Friday, arriving in time to
practice. The squad ate lunch, dinner, and a Saturday morning meal together. This schedule helps to settle a team down and makes for a better organized and
cooperative effort.
The 1950 team played four years without an intercollegiate loss, winning four straight national championships. In its senior year, it conveyed an impression of invulnerability. The 1984 team, prior to their
undefeated national championship season, suffered an
occasional loss, including heartbreaking defeats in
three preceding championship finals.
A clear cut comparison indicates the 1950 team produced two first team All-Americans, one second team,
and two third team selections. Over its four years, including honorable mentions, the 1950 team generated
a total of 41 All-Americans. The entire 1950 first team
earned All-America recognition some time during its
four years. Interestingly, over their four years, eleven
1950 players were named to the All-Time J HU Team,
nine in the year 1950 alone, which is more than any
team in the university's history, before or since.
The 1984 squad produced four first team AllAmericans, two second team and one third team selection. Over its four years, including honorable mention,
the team generated a total of 28 All-Americans. During the four year span from 1981 to 1984, two players
were named to the All-Time JHU Team.
The supreme honor lacrosse can bestow is election

Scott:Zim Can Take the Pressure

18LAX/MARCH 8, 1985

Midfield, Goal Are Strengths of Talented Jays
Continued from Page 3

Single's ability to put the ball on goal and to get open
for high-percentage shots. In spite of his limited experience, Zimmerman is very high on Single's talents
and expects him to be a major part of the attack unit.
"Bill does the things a creaseman needs to do," said
Zimmerman."He also hangs in there on the screens."
Thielemann improved greatly last year and peaked
with a three-goal Performance against Rutgers. This
pre-season he has played well, scoring mostly from the
crease area, although Zimmerman has indicated he
would not use Thielemann as the creaseman. It is

possible Thielemann will start some games this season,
though he should see abundant playing time regardless
of his role. "A versatile, steady player," is Zimmerman's description,"who is capable of spelling any of
the three starters." If his progess continues, this
Centennial product should emerge as a big contributor.
Morrill, an All-American at St. Paul's High School
last year, has already shown he has the talent to
challenge both Single and Thielemann for the third
starting position. Zimmerman sees Morrill as a strong,
heady player who can do well either in the crease or
behind the goal. Chances are that Morrill will not start
versus Syracuse, but Zimmerman probably will not

hesitate to use him should the offense sputter.
Ciccarone is another Baltimore product and the
third brother to play for Hopkins, following Henry
and Brent. An All-American at Boy's Latin prep
school, Ciccarone should see limited action this
year as Zimmerman has indicated he'll be used
primarily as a left-handed back-up.
,Nordberg transferred from Maryland two years ago,
but has yet to play on the squad. He has played fairly
well throughout pre-season, though it is doubtful he
will see much action this year unless there is a rash of
injuries or Hopkins is routing an opponent.
_

Leading Hopkins' second midfield unit will be
Mutscheller. A quick cutter to the crease, Mutscheller
has become a good, smart inside player, according to
Zimmerman, and should have his best games versus
opponents playing a zone defense. As the seventh
leading scorer for the Jays last year, Mutscheller will
be expected to carry a large part of the scoring load
and to fill the void left by Tucker, his former linemate.
While his performance will depend to some extent on
whoever is feeding from behind the net, Mutscheller
should be one of the midfield's top five contributors.
Schreiber will team with Mutscheller and give the
second line diversity with his ability to drive to the goal
from the outside. Big and strong, Schreiber has shown
that he can muscle over defenders, which should open
things up inside fol- his linemates. The junior scored
11 goals last year, including three in the semifinal
playoff game versus Carolina, but had only one assist"
all season. He will need to pass more if this line is to
be successful against Hopkins' stronger opponents.
Chanenchuk will be breaking into the top two midfields after playing infrequently on the third line and
for many clears last season. Said Zimmerman,
"Chanenchuk is one of the niftiest players, but is
relatively new to playing midfield. He needs to continue to improve on defense." A Farmingdale, New
York product, Chanenchuk will probably play on the
same line with former high school teammate
Krumenacker, which should help him all around. To
be successful, however, he will need to improve on his
shot, which is somewhat weak.
While Castle did not play much during the second
half of the 1984 season, he will also be on one of the
top two lines. A quick and extremely fast middie with
a very hard outside shot, Castle will pose a threat to
any defense. He should be especially helpful against
zones, where his shot will keep the Jays' opponents
honest.
Crawford continues in much the same capacity as
last year, when he impressed many Hopkins fans with
his all-out play on the third midfield line. This
sophomore had only one goal and assist, but netted
12 groundballs. "Jack gives 100 percent all the time,"
said Zimmerman. "He's relentless and does the things
you need him to do. He's going to play."
John Dressel, a two-time high school All-America,

is the second third line member.The Lawrenceville product has had an average pre-season, but "possesses
a wealth of ability," according to Zimmerman. He
may see extra action on clears.
Rzempoluch is the newest member of the Farmingdale Connection. He will team with Crawford and
Dressel on the third line and may face-off occasionally.
Stewart will play occasionally and may also faceoff. He had a good fall, according to Zimmerman,and
has worked hard preparing for the season.
Diorio will also play infrequently, though his role
may change as the season progresses. When he does
see action it will probably be on clears.
Webster is a walk-on and this will be his first season
with the team.
One of the biggest factors in Hopkins' last two
championship games was ball control off the faceoffs.
In 1983, Syracuse dominated late in the game and was
able to launch its tremendous comeback. Last year, Hopkins jumped out to an early lead as it won nearly
every faceoff in the first quarter, and held off Syracuse
later on as the faceoff unit retained control of the ball.
This season, the Blue Jays will be even stronger as
they return all three of their specialists, Greg Matthews, Lee Davidson and Glenn Fidje, and add potential depth with middies Joe Rzempoluch and Damon
Stewart.
Matthews took the majority of faceoffs last season
(64 percent) and dominated in almost every game, winning just over three-fifths of them. He also had 84
groundballs and won the Ciccarone Ground Ball
Award for his efforts. This was a vast improvement
over the 1983 season when he had a modest 55. The
senior can only improve this year, and if his progress
is as dramatic as last year, he may dominate totally.
Davidson saw considerable action as well, taking a
quarter of the faceoffs and winning over 64 percent,
best on the team. He also scored four goals and added an assist while scooping up 35 groundballs. Davidson will most likely be Matthews' main challenger for
the number one position.
Fidge didn't see much action, facing-off only 30
times, but he did win 63 percent and grabbed-up 14
groundballs. He will have to work hard to beat out
his teammates.

MIDFIELD
If you subscribe to the theory that games are won
at midfield, you'll be happy to know that the middies
comprise Hopkins' strongest unit and are probably-the
best midfields in the nation. This is largely the result
of the Jays' small losses and their typically strong
recruiting effort. Hopkins lost only three players from
this unit as honorable mention All-America John
Tucker and Rich Glancy were graduated, and
freshman Tom Engelke transferred to Nassau County Junior College.
Returning for the Blue Jays are first team AllAmerica and Division I Midfielder of the Year Del
Dressel and second team All-America John
Krumenacker from the starting line, and juniors Steve
Mutscheller and Chris Schreiber from the second line.
The Jays also return seniors Glenn Fidje, Lee Davidson, and Greg Matthews, junior Dave Castle, and
sophomores Bruce Chanenchuk, Jack Crawford,
Damon Stewart, and Joe Diorio. New players include
sophomore Mike Webster and freshman recruits Joe
Rzempoluch and John Dressel.
Del Dressel is generally regarded as the best midfielder on the squad, having been, by far, the highest
scoring middie for the last two years. He has also been
very consistent, netting 27 goals each year with an
average of 18 assists. Additionally, Dressel has been
a veritable ball hog, scooping up 59 groundballs last
season while taking well over 100 shots. Perhaps his
greatest asset, though, is his ability to lead the transition fast breaks and to score when the team needs
a goal. This season, Dressel should continue to
dominate at midfield, as he takes one step closer
toward becoming only the third four-time first team
All-American in collegiate lacrosse history.
The second big gun in this unit is tri-captain
Krumenacker. Despite having a somewhat disappointing season offensively in 1984, Zimmerman is confident in this senior's talents and his ability to bounce
back to peak form. "John does a great job defensively and is very good at setting up the other players,"
said Zimmerman. "He just needs to concentrate at
putting the ball on net." In addition, nobody on the
team executes the clear as well as Krumenacker,
especially against the tough riders such as North
Carolina. Should "Boomer" regain his accuracy, he
will undoubtedly fill opponents' nets this season.

DEFENSE
pend to a large extent on Matricciani's ability to keep
the crease clear.
Pallace will fill Steve Dubin's spot among the
starters after spending last year on the rope unit. Termed "A Gamer" by Zimmerman, this Calvert Hall product scooped up 15 groundballs last season, while committing but one penalty. According to the coach,
Pallace "has been practicing and playing extremely
well," and his continually improving, consistent play
should help solidify the defensive unit.

The Game of Lacrosse
U

Lacrosse, in its original form, was widely played by
North American Indians as early as the 1600's. It was
described in accounts by European settlers, who
observed unruly competitions among hundreds of
competitors which lasted from many hours to many
days. The game was to the Indians a source of recreation and a means of preparation of warriors.
Lacrosse today has incorporated the essentials of a
good spectator sport. Its principles are basic: Two
teams of ten players each compete on an open field
110 yards long, with the object of shooting a hard rubber ball into the opposing net. The restrictions which
make the game unique are that a player may only control the ball by maneuvering it with a large stick capped by a small net(although the ball may also be kicked). Armed with this weapon, the player can pass,
bounce, and shoot the ball with remarkable accuracy.
The game itself lasts 60 minutes on the college level,
with stoppage of play for goals, penalties, and outof-bounds. Penalties include the following: offsides,
violated when a team has fewer than three men on the
offensive side of the field or fewer than four on the
defensive side; crease violations; unsportsmanlike conduct; and rough play violations, including pushing,
slashing, and illegal checking.
Among the ten men on the field, three attackmen
remain on the offensive half of the field, three
defensemen occupy the defensive half, and three midfielders traverse the entire field. The goalie directly
guards the goal and is provided with a circular crease
which the opposing team may not enter.
Strict restrictions are placed on the sticks, which are
limited in material and dimensions. Illegal sticks draw
severe penalties.
Rules concerning possession in lacrosse are different
'than many other sports. Turnovers occur when a ball
in one team's possession is lost out of bounds or when
a penalty occurs. Another rule unique to lacrosse states
that a shot on goal which goes out of bounds is given
to the player that was closest to the ball when it left
the field.
Lacrosse is a game which is constantly in motion.,
The officials attempt to keep the game moving as
quickly as possible by starting the clock as soon as the
ball is ready. A game will last two hours or more
Without a boring moment.
Lacrosse at Johns Hopkins
Most of us have heard this before. It appears in
every lacrosse program. Despite the incessant repitition, the statistics are rather awesome:
Since receiving official recognition from the university in 1888, the Johns Hopkins Blue Jays have. . .
°won or shared 40 national championships
*compiled 73 winning seasons, only 13 losing ones, and
11 even, for a seasonal victory mark of 80 percent..
'produced 131 first team All-America selections since
the first team was chosen in 1922.
*placed 40 members in the present 147-member
Lacrosse Hall of Fame.
*twice represented the United States in the Olympic
Games.
'won 5 NCAA championships since the tournament
began in 1971.
Most Hopkins students enter the school knowing little about the game and leave as trained experts. Games
are very well attended and attract a wide variety of people from the community and the lacrosse world in
general. Tickets this year cost three dollars, but don't
worry: admission is free with a student ID.
